title: Chinese community donates ambulances as a way to give back to New Zealand's multi-culture society
content:
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 21 (Xinhua) -- Chao Shan community's chairman said on Saturday that its ambulance donation to Christchurch emergency service provider St John is a way of giving back to New Zealand multi-culture society.
"We are contributing our share to the harmony and prosperity of New Zealand multi-culture society. The ambulances that we donated are our way of helping those in need in the local community," said Chen Zhi, chairman of New Zealand Chao Shan General Association, adding that they were also working with St John for further commitments.
The two new ambulances, worth over 230,000 New Zealand dollars (151,800 U.S. dollars), have began their service from this week with full emergency equipment installed.
A special dedication ceremony was held on Monday at the St John Christchurch ambulance hub.
St John South Island Regional Manager Craig Stockdale said the two new ambulances will enable ambulance officers to continue their daily life-saving work.
Christchurch Mayor Lianne Dalziel acknowledged Chao Shan General Association for its generosity and commitment to New Zealand social services at the ceremony.
In response to the March 15 terrorist attack in Christchurch, members of the New Zealand Chao Shan General Association and Teochew International Federation gave more than 2 million NZ dollars (1.32 million dollars) to the Christchurch Foundation's Our People Our City fund, requesting the funds go towards ambulances for the church.
Chen said the association wanted to recognise the bravery of the St John ambulance officers who responded to the events of March 15.
